UK

UK PM May said there is no Brexit deal available that does not have a backstop, while PM May added that she is seeking assurances the backstop is temporary. (Newswires)

A UK senior government source was said to be expecting a confidence vote imminently and there were also reports that the 1922 Committee is set to meet on Wednesday evening. Furthermore, there were reports that Brady has asked to see the PM after pmqs tomorrow and that multiple sources believe the threshold of 48 letters has been reached, although there were separate reports that friends of Brady said he has no plans to make a statement about a confidence vote on UK PM May's leadership. UK Junior Brexit Minister Walker said if there is no deal before January 21st the government will arrange a debate in parliament, while Walker added that in all scenarios, UK will need to have a meaningful vote before the aforementioned date. (Newswires)

UK officials are reportedly warning EU members that a "no deal" Brexit raises the risk of financial disruption to banks. (Sky News)

PoliticsHome's Schofield tweeted that a senior non-ERG Tory MP said they believed the Prime Minister will be "gone by Monday" and that several more letters of confidence had gone in since yesterday over Brexit vote fiasco. Furthermore, ERG sources were said to be pretty confident now that 48 trigger has been breached according to SkyNews political editor, although HuffPost's Paul Waugh noted shortly after that he was told list keeper Graham Brady has NOT got an announcement to make about the 48 letters. (Twitter)

US

US President Trump said he will shut down the government if there is no wall on border. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

Stocks opened higher following progressive US-China trade developments before drifting lower through the day, trade sensitive semiconductors (AVGO, MU, TXN, INTC) and industrials (CAT, DE) started the session as outperformers. After reports China would be reducing car tariffs, automakers (GM, F, FCAU, TSLA) pushed higher on the open. AT&T (T) outperformed in earlier trade on the back of an upgrade at Citi. The energy sector traded higher on the open and then drifted lower, in line with oil prices, also suppressed by a string of downgrades in the sector by JPMorgan. Pfizer (PFE) weighed down healthcare following a downgrade at JPMorgan. Financials (WFC, BLK, GS, C) underperformed as yields moved lower. SPX -0.04% at 2637, NDX +0.32% at 6704, DJI -0.22% at 24370.

Treasuries traded lower in Asia amid low volume and continued to sell into the European open. As US traders sat at their desks, the complex edged gradually higher and extended gains on reports suggesting Trump administration is condemning China over hacking and economic espionage Trump administration to condemn China over hacking and economic espionage as well as Trump threatening a government shutdown. Nonetheless the complex finished Tuesday’s session in negative territory as equities pared back some of their losses and turned positive heading into the close.  Most of the action was concentrated in the front end of the curve where yields were higher by c.5bps at settlement. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 7+ ticks lower at 120-14+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 11th December: Trump renews govt shutdown threat; EU unwilling to re-open Brexit negotiations
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.
 

US MARKET WRAP – 11th December: Trump renews govt shutdown threat; EU unwilling to re-open Brexit negotiations

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, treasuries down, dollar up, crude up.   

* REAR-VIEW: Trump threatens govt shutdown if wall funds aren’t allocated; China to cut US auto tariffs; Spectre of UK PM May confidence vote rises; Italy looks to EU as France budget likely to exceed 3%/GDP in 2019; US 3-year auction tails 0.3bps.

* AHEAD: Weekly crude inventories AMC, Swiss CPI, US CPI & Real Weekly Earnings, Brazilian Interest Rate Decision, OPEC Monthly Report, UK GBP 0.5bln I/L 2048 Gilt Auction, US USD 24bln 10yr Auction.

 

* US GOVERNMENT SHUTDOWN: US President Trump claimed he will shut down the government if there is no wall on border between the US and Mexico; at the meeting the President defended his position noting that the wall will be built "one way or another" after both Vice President Mike Pence and House Minority Leader Republican Pelosi warned there are not enough votes to fund the USD 5bln wall.

* BREXIT: UK PM May headed to Brussels on Tuesday to seek reassurances from the EU after meaningful vote on her deal was called off in parliament on Tuesday. European Council President Tusk said to have held "long and frank discussion" with the British PM and showed willingness to help but the question remains how. Meanwhile, there were conflicting reports from ERG sources suggesting that 48 letters to trigger a vote of no confidence in her leadership have been submitted by MPs; some have suggested the number has been reached while others believe they are close to hitting the 48 letters threshold. In late trade, a UK senior government source is expecting a confidence vote imminently.

* TRADE: China was said to make a proposal in order to cut tariffs on US auto imports to 15% from 40%; while the offer has been submitted for review, the decision has not been finalised and could still change. This followed Trump’s tweet post-G20 meeting announcing that China had agreed to cut auto tariffs, a concession that wasn’t however reflected in the official statement. As such, market participants were unclear whether China was truly committed to achieving a deal with regards to autos, or whether US President Trump had embellished the outcome of his meeting with China. Today's news suggested that such an agreement was discussed, and as such, is positive in terms of taking steps to resolve the trade dispute. Elsewhere, the Washington Post reported that the Trump administration is to condemn China over hacking and economic espionage, escalating tensions between superpowers. Also, US House Representatives have introduced a bill that would ban the sale of US goods to Chinese telecom firms who are in violation of US export and sanctions laws. With regards to the Huawei CFO arrest, the Canadian Judge is set to make a decision on the bail at 1400 pacific time (2200 GMT) while earlier reports suggested the US State Department is mulling travel advisory for China to caution the US.

*  ITALY: An Italian Government source stated that there are "excellent" chances that the EU will not discipline Italy if they provide a deficit/GDP target for 2019 of 2.0% though neither party wants to lower deficit/GDP target to below 2.2%.  Finance Minister Tria said once again the government will not make major changes to the budget; adds Italy's fiscal targets may be revised and is confident an EDP can be avoided.

* FRANCE: The European Commission announced it will revise the 2019 French budget in the spring when economic forecasts will also be released. The recent measures introduced to calm the Yellow Vests protests are anticipated to have an impact on the budget figure; these include fuel-tax cuts, a monthly bonus for those on minimum wages, and no extra taxes for those retired and earning less than EUR 2,000. The Budget Minister currently sees the 2019 public deficit at 2.5% of GDP (excluding the one-off impact of payroll tax rebate transformation) though noted that expenditure could amount to around EUR 10bln, adding 0.5 percentage point to the 2019 deficit and boost the gap to 3.4 percent of GDP.

* US PPI rose 0.1% in November, decelerating from the 0.6% in October amid a slump in oil prices. Looking at the other components, airline fares were up 2.3% while transportation costs by road and rail rose around 1% on the back of labour and truck shortages. The Core measure rose 0.3% (Oct. 0.5%) and may have peaked for this cycle. Analysts at Pantheon note that oil prices have a greater influence on PPI inflation compared to CPI or PCE and argue that “the plunge in crude prices soon will start to work its way through production and distribution costs” and therefore anticipate the core measures “ to slow sharply over the next six-to-nine months, with a big drop likely to start before the end of the winter”.

* WTI (F9) SETTLES USD 0.65 HIGHER AT USD 51.65/BBL, BRENT (F9) SETTLES USD 0.23 HIGHER AT USD 60.20/BBL.  Crude trades higher, helped in the early part of the day by improved equity market sentiment, which was driven by suggestions that US/China trade talks are ongoing. However, that sentiment proved temporary, and stocks slid as Trump threatened a government shutdown, dragging oil with it, leaving the complex mixed going into settlement. Some analysts continue to suggest that the OPEC deal reached last week should help to turn around crude sentiment; "the OPEC+ cut agreement achieved last Friday represents a strong statement of intent to defend the oil price in the face of internal political difficulties and pressure from the US to allow the price to fall further," UBS said. "The 1.2mln BPD cut agreed should also be more than enough to swing the market from a small surplus into a deficit both in the near-term and for 2019 if OPEC chooses to maintain the cuts beyond the current 6-month plan." UBS suggests that it could be a failure to achieve a cut agreement at or above the top of the 1mln to 1.4mln BPD consensus range, but its oil analyst said he cannot believe that sentiment will remain so relentlessly negative as the impact of the production cuts, continued production declines from Venezuela and Iran and outages in Libya filter through the fundamental data in coming weeks." Elsewhere, the IEA's STEO saw world oil demand in 2018 raised by 20k BPD to 1.54mln BPD YY; 2019 forecast was raised by 80k BPD to 1.52mln BPD YY. For output, the EIA forecast 2019 US crude oil output will rise by 1.18mln BPD (prev. 1.16mln) to 12.06mln BPD. This week’s oil inventories data see crude -3.0mln, distillate +1.8mln, gasoline +2.5mln.

* SPX -0.04% at 2637, NDX +0.32% at 6704, DJI -0.22% at 24370. SECTORS: Energy +0.03%, Materials -0.36%, Industrials -0.59%, Cons Discretionary +0.04%, Cons Staples +0.85%, Healthcare +0.30%, Financials -1.02%, Tech +0.09%, Telecoms +0.15%, Utilities +0.30%.

*STOCK SPECIFICS: Stocks opened higher following progressive US-China trade developments before drifting lower through the day, trade sensitive semiconductors (AVGO, MU, TXN, INTC) and industrials (CAT, DE) started the session as outperformers. After reports China would be reducing car tariffs, automakers (GM, F, FCAU, TSLA) pushed higher on the open. AT&T (T) outperformed in earlier trade on the back of an upgrade at Citi. The energy sector traded higher on the open and then drifted lower, in line with oil prices, also suppressed by a string of downgrades in the sector by JPMorgan. Pfizer (PFE) weighed down healthcare following a downgrade at JPMorgan. Financials (WFC, BLK, GS, C) underperformed as yields moved lower.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE 7+ TICKS LOWER AT 120-14+. Treasuries traded lower in Asia amid low volume and continued to sell into the European open. As US traders sat at their desks, the complex edged gradually higher and extended gains on reports suggesting Trump administration is condemning China over hacking and economic espionage Trump administration to condemn China over hacking and economic espionage as well as Trump threatening a government shutdown. Nonetheless the complex finished Tuesday’s session in negative territory as equities pared back some of their losses and turned positive heading into the close.  Most of the action was concentrated in the front end of the curve where yields were higher by c.5bps at settlement.

The treasury sold USD 38bln in 3-year notes tailing by 0.3bps at a high yield of 2.748%, the lowest since July. Demand for the auction, as indicated by the bid-to-cover, was slightly below recent averages. Looking at the breakdown, directs participation rebounded from recent weakness as directs secured the biggest share since July 2016; indirects were awarded the largest share since June and primary dealers were left with the smallest portion since January.

* 10-YEAR NOTES PREVIEW: The US Treasury will auction USD 38bln of 3-year notes (Tues), USD 24bln of 10-year notes (Wed) and USD 16bln of 30-year bonds (Thu). With 10-year yields beneath the November auction stop-out rate (and all the stop-out rates going to July), analysts at SocGen say Wednesday’s auction will likely be “under pressure”. “On relative value metrics, the current note is trading rich on the Treasury spline versus old 10s compared with the previous two cycles, while it has slightly cheapened over the past two sessions on the curve versus 5s and 30s, though it is still rich compared with the previous auction levels,” the bank writes. It also suggests that the recent flattening of the 2s10s curve could be a negative, as well as the recent increase in dealer holdings. It is also worth noting that ahead of the auction, the November CPI data will be released, which could influence the tone of the auction. On the flip side, SocGen notes that current 10s are trading special in repo, which indicates a short base, which could offset headwinds.

* AUD, NZD, SEK, NOK: All benefiting from a pronounced rebound in risk appetite, prompted in part by positive developments on the US-China trade front following reports about constructive dialogue between Washington and Beijing, and news that the latter has put forward proposals to slash US auto tariffs to 15% from 40% for review. Aud/Usd is consolidating recovery gains above 0.7200, with the Kiwi back within striking distance of 0.6900, while Eur/Sek and Eur/Nok have retreated below 9.7000 and 10.3000 respectively post-forecast beating Norwegian inflation data yesterday and pre-Swedish CPI on Wednesday.

* EUR: The single currency has dropped to the bottom of the G10 pile and through 1.1350 support vs the Dollar that held on Monday amidst heightened Eurozone fiscal concerns in the run up to Wednesday’s 2019 draft budget representation from Italy to the EU. Rome’s coalition parties and key Government officials are still at loggerheads over how far to bridge the gap between Brussels’ demands and the initial 2.4% deficit target that was rejected and threatens the imposition of EDP measures. However, the Eur came under additional pressure from French President Macron’s climbdown to quell civil unrest and the prospect of an even bigger overshoot in public finances vs GDP in Paris next year. Eur/Usd has retreated further from 1.1400 as a result and now eyeing bids/support just ahead of 1.1300.

* JPY, GBP, CAD, CHF: The Jpy appears to have eluded another test of a key fib level around 113.34, but equally could not gather enough recovery momentum to breach resistance at 113.00 and a decent option expiry at the strike (1.5 bn) as the aforementioned revival in risk appetite kept the safe-haven in check. Similarly, the Pound failed to sustain its return to 1.2600+ status and recoiled in sympathy (to a degree) with the Eur) amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty, even though UK average earnings were upbeat towards 1.2550. However, the Loonie and Franc both held up better against the backdrop of a firmer Greenback overall in wake of stronger than forecast US core PPI (DXY up to 97.358 vs 96.867 at one stage) with the aid of higher oil and relative gains vs the single currency. Hence, Usd/Cad continued to pivot 1.3400, and while Usd/Chf climbed back above 0.9900, Eur/Chf stayed nearer the base of 1.1225-60 trading parameters.

subject: PREVIEW: US to sell USD 38bln in 3-year notes
content:
The US Treasury will auction USD 38bln of 3-year notes (Tues), USD 24bln of 10-year notes (Wed) and USD 16bln of 30-year bonds (Thu). Analysts have suggested that demand at 3-year auctions has not kept up pace with the rising auction sizes. Barclays points out that bid-to-cover ratios have been trending lower in recent auction cycles (falling from 3.1x at the start of the year, to 2.5x at the previous auction; tail sizes have also been of note; in the first half of the year, 3-year auctions stopped through by 0.1bps on average, though in the second half of the year, has seen an average tail size of 0.3bps. Barclays also observes that direct bidder participation has also declined, falling to near post-crisis lows. “This was largely due to a smaller takedown from domestic investors, falling from 42% in October to 35% in November,” Barclays says, “broker dealers have had to take down more in recent months.”

Recent history

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Antipodean Dollars and Scandi Crowns outperform on turnaround Tuesday AUD/
content:
AUD/NZD/SEK/NOK

All benefiting from a pronounced rebound in risk appetite, prompted in part by positive developments on the US-China trade front following reports about constructive dialogue between Washington and Beijing, and news that the latter has put forward proposals to slash US auto tariffs to 15% from 40% for review. Aud/Usd is consolidating recovery gains above 0.7200, with the Kiwi back within striking distance of 0.6900, while Eur/Sek and Eur/Nok have retreated below 9.7000 and 10.3000 respectively post-forecast beating Norwegian inflation data yesterday and pre-Swedish CPI on Wednesday.

EUR

The single currency has dropped to the bottom of the G10 pile and through 1.1350 support vs the Dollar that held on Monday amidst heightened Eurozone fiscal concerns in the run up to Wednesday’s 2019 draft budget representation from Italy to the EU. Rome’s coalition parties and key Government officials are still at loggerheads over how far to bridge the gap between Brussels’ demands and the initial 2.4% deficit target that was rejected and threatens the imposition of EDP measures. However, the Eur came under additional pressure from French President Macron’s climbdown to quell civil unrest and the prospect of an even bigger overshoot in public finances vs GDP in Paris next year. Eur/Usd has retreated further from 1.1400 as a result and now eyeing bids/support just ahead of 1.1300.

JPY/GBP/CAD/CHF

The Jpy appears to have eluded another test of a key fib level around 113.34, but equally could not gather enough recovery momentum to breach resistance at 113.00 and a decent option expiry at the strike (1.5 bn) as the aforementioned revival in risk appetite kept the safe-haven in check. Similarly, the Pound failed to sustain its return to 1.2600+ status and recoiled in sympathy (to a degree) with the Eur) amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty, even though UK average earnings were upbeat towards 1.2550. However, the Loonie and Franc both held up better against the backdrop of a firmer Greenback overall in wake of stronger than forecast US core PPI (DXY up to 97.358 vs 96.867 at one stage) with the aid of higher oil and relative gains vs the single currency. Hence, Usd/Cad continued to pivot 1.3400, and while Usd/Chf climbed back above 0.9900, Eur/Chf stayed nearer the base of 1.1225-60 trading parameters.

  • Stitch Fix (SFIX) Q1 EPS USD 0.10 vs. Exp. USD 0.03, revenue USD 0.366bln vs. Exp. USD 0.357bln. The co. does not expect an increase in subscribers during holiday period. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – Tigress Financial has said the recent selloff in the tech giant is a “major buying opportunity”. Elsewhere, Wedbush has said the latest Qualcomm (QCOM) China court ruling is another “gut punch” for the co. Additionally, the tech giant launched its mobile payments service in Germany, four years after it started in the US and competing with Google (GOOGL) that launched its service in the country in June. (Newswires)
  • Disney (DIS), Fox (FOXA) – After failing to sell in bulk the 22 Fox regional sports networks, Disney is now planning to sell them individually. (NY Post)
  • IBM (IBM), Red Hat (RHT) – Red Hat is having a shareholder meeting on January 16th, 2019 for its merger with IBM. (Newswires)
  • Intel (INTC) – The NY Times reports that Intel will face increasing competition from Amazon (AMZN) after it finished developing its new computer chip. (NY Times)
  • Merck (MRK) – The pharma giant has appointed Michael Nally is its new Chief Marketing Officer amongst a range of other management changes. (Newswires)
  • Verizon (VZ) - Following its separation of its wireless Oath unit, the telecoms conglomerate expects a USD 1.3bln-1.8bln after tax severance charge in Q4, it also expects to realise USD 2.1bln in deferred tax benefits and expects a non-cash USD 4.6bln goodwill impairment charge. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) – The retailer, alongside Rakuten, have opened the first Walmart ecommerce store in Japan. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Automakers (F, FCAU, GM, TSLA) – Auto names are gaining momentum pre-market after reports suggesting China is reportedly moving to cut auto tariffs on US cars. (Newswires)
  • BNY Mellon (BK) – The co. announced a USD 830mln increase to its stock repurchase programme. (Newswires)
  • CBS (CBS) – The broadcaster has sold its CBS Television City property to Hackman Capital Partners for USD 750mln. Separately, it has made little progress in finding a successor to former CEO Leslie Mooves, the WSJ reported. (Newswires/WSJ)
  • Costco (COST) – The wholesaler has had its Q1 EPS estimate raised at Baird, citing stronger sales. (Newswires)
  • CVS Health (CVS) – Leerink rated the stock “outperform” citing optimism from its acquisition of Aetna (AET). (Newswires)
  • FedEx (FDX), UPS (UPS) – The Trump administration is mulling new measures to allow the US Postal Service to charge for mailbox access to other shipping co.s as it is currently unprofitable. (WSJ)
  • Lockheed Martin (LMT) – The defence group appointed new CFO Kenneth Possenriede to succede Bruce L. Tanner, who is looking to retire in mid-2019. (Newswires)
  • Northrop Grumman (NOC) – The aerospace and defence co. is changing its accounting methods for its pensions which is expected to increase its net FAS/CAS adjustment to USD 1.35bln from USD 750mln and increase pre-tax earnings by USD 600mln. (Newswires)
  • Southern Co. (SO) – The electric co. has appointed Dr. Janaki Akella and Anthony Earley to its board of directors. (Newswires)
  • Under Armour (UA, UAA) – The sportswear apparel co. has fired two executives after a review of their expenses. (WSJ)
  • United Continental (UAL) – The airline reported November traffic up 7.1% and capacity up 5.5%. (Newswires)

NASDAQ

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – CEO Sundar Pichai is to face the US House Judiciary Committee today over a range of questions, particularly on the co.’s handling of data and election meddling. Pichai is reportedly planning to express his support for privacy data laws and denial of any political bias. Elsewhere, Verge reports that human rights activist have sent a letter to Pichai urging the co. not to continue with its censored China search engine Dragonfly. (Newswires/Verge)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – There is “wild speculation” that the retailer could be purchasing the UK supermarket Morissons (MRW LN). (FT)
  • Facebook (FB) – The co.’s Instagram unit has appointed previous product executive Vishal Shah as its new head of product. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) - CEO Elon Musk tweets of the electric automaker opening new shops/service centres next year. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Cars.com (CARS) – Automotive website is facing pressure form shareholder Starboard Value for strategic alternatives including a break up. (Newswires)
  • Enbridge (ENB) – The co. has increased its quarterly dividend by 10% for 2019, reaffirms 10% annual growth through 2020, sees 2018 DCF in the upper range of USD 4.15-4.45, announces USD 1.8bln of capital investments. (Newswires)
  • Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) – The co. announced a USD 400mln increase to its share repurchase programme. (Newswires)
  • Latam Airlines (LTM) – The airline reported November system passenger traffic increased by 5.1% compared with November 2017, capacity increased by 6.4% and load factor fell 1.1 ppts to 83.2%. (Newswires)
  • Spirit AeroSystems (SPRO) – The co. named Jose Ignacio Garcia CFO. (Newswires)
  • WPP (WPP) – The PR co. is making a range of cost cutting efforts amounting to GBP 300mln over three years, including cutting 3,500 jobs; it expects its FY18/19 results in line with expectations. (Newswires/FT)

subject: UK Labour party debate in UK House of Commons expected at 1400GMT
RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 11th December 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • China reportedly looking to move forward with US Auto Tariff reduction lifts equity futures further as risk-on tone returns
  • Cable climbing as UK PM May returns to Brussels for compromise
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US PPI, US 3yr Note Auction, PM May meeting EU’s Juncker & Tusk

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mixed as sentiment in the region only found mild solace from the tech-led recovery on Wall St. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was firmer at the open in which outperformance in the tech sector helped the index pick itself up from around 2-year lows although this later stalled amid weakness in energy and financials, while Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) swung between gains and losses due to a lack of fresh drivers and an indecisive currency. Shanghai Comp. (+0.4) and Hang Seng (unch.) were also choppy on trade uncertainty amid lingering concerns the Huawei situation could spill-over to US-China trade talks, although there were reports that Vice Premier Liu spoke with US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and US Trade Representative Lighthizer in which they exchanged views on pushing forward the timetable and road map for the next stages of trade discussions. Meanwhile, India markets were initially pressured following the shock resignation by RBI Governor Patel which many viewed to be in protest for government meddling, while the state assembly elections added to the woes for the government with the ruling BJP party on track to lose some states to the main opposition ahead of next year’s general election. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful amid the indecisive risk tone and with participants following mixed results at the 30yr JGB auction.

PBoC skipped repos although are expected to resume operations soon to fill year-end short-term liquidity gaps. (Newswires/CSJ)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8996 (Prev. 6.8693)

China Mofcom said Vice Premier Liu He spoke by phone with US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade Representative Lighthizer in which both sides exchanged views on implementing consensus reached by their leaders, while they also exchanged views on pushing forward timetable and road map for next stage of trade discussions. (Newswires)

China is to announce details of fist purchase of US soybeans, in which most will be added to state reserves. (Newswires)

Huawei CFO bail hearing ended without a decision and will resume today. Reports also noted that Canada Crown commented on the defence’s proposal of CAD 15mln for bail of Huawei CFO in which it stated that bail should be half cash and half home equity, while the judge was said to want a house arrest for Huawei CFO. (Newswires)

TRADE

China is said to be moving on the US auto tariffs reduction that US President Trump has previously tweeted on. The proposal has been submitted for review, however, the decision has not been finalised and still could change (Newswires)

UK/EU/US

Politics Home journalist tweets "Steve Baker calls on Tory MPs to now submit enough letters of confidence in Theresa May to ‘bring her down’; Steve Baker says Esther McVey, Dominic Raab, David Davis and Boris Johnson ‘need to work out between which one of them is to be our candidate’ to be new Tory leader"
 

Irish Foreign Minister Coveney says backstop itself is not going to change, adding that the Irish government has no issue providing reassurance around the backstop. Is bringing a detailed paper to the cabinet on Tuesday on various Brexit scenarios; including a no deal. (Newswires)

House of Commons leader Leadsom says PM May might get an addendum to the withdrawal agreement, adding that there are plenty of options for PM may to speak with EU leaders on. (Newswires)

EU's Juncker says reopening the withdrawal agreement is not going to happen; but further clarifications are possible. (Newswires)
 

German European Affairs Minister Roth says he does not see scope to change the Brexit deal. When asked if German Chancellor Merkel can help PM May on Wednesday, he stated that it is always good to talk with each other. (Newswires)

FT Brussels Correspondent tweets, EU sources insisting this morning that May won't get a clarification on the backstop that will carry any legal weight. (Twitter)

Times Journalist Sam Coates reports that SNP, Lib Dems and others have written to Labour's Jeremy Corbyn to push for a no confidence motion in UK PM May. (Newswires)

UK PM May Spokesperson says that the Govt. will bring back the deal to parliament for a vote before January 21st. (Newswires)

UK Average Week Earnings 3M YY Oct 3.3% vs. Exp. 3.0% (Prev. 3.0%, Rev. 3.1%)

UK Average Earnings (Ex-Bonus) Oct 3.3% vs. Exp. 3.2% (Prev. 3.2%)

UK Employment Change (Oct) 79k vs. Exp. 25k (Prev. 23k)

Following French President Macron’s announcements reports suggest the 2019 deficit/GDP ratio is likely to be around 3.5%. (Les Echos)

Reported that Italian PM Conte is targeting a 2.1% deficit, however, separate reports suggest, Deputy PMs Salvini and Di Maio refuse a deficit of below 2.2%, whilst the EU are reportedly demanding a deficit target of 1.95%. (La Repubblica/Messaggero)

Italian Government source says there are "excellent" chances that the EU will not discipline Italy if they provide a deficit/GDP target for 2019 of 2.0%. Neither party wants to lower deficit/GDP target to below 2.2%; PM Conte is unlikely to suggest any new target at Wednesday meeting with Juncker. (Newswires)

US President Trump is said to be concerned regarding an impeachment and sees it as a real possibility according to sources. (CNN)

CENTRAL BANKS

India's Finance Minister states that he is not in favour of selecting an interim RBI governor but wants one appointed by the next meeting; announcement likely today. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European Indices are in the green [Euro Stoxx 50 +1.6%], with some outperformance seen in the SMI (+1.6%) bolstered by strong performance in index heavyweight Novartis (+1.6%) after the FDA approved Pear Therapeutics mobile application, which their Sandoz unit will be rolling out in the US. The SMI is also bolstered by LafargeHolcim (+3.6%), which is benefitting from outperformance in the materials sector seen today on the back of US and Chinese representatives planning the next steps in trade discussions. FTSE 100 (+1.3%) is lagging its peers, amidst currency effects from ongoing Brexit developments. Other notable equity movers are WPP (+6.5%) after an update to guidance, and Ashtead Group (+4.2%) after they announced full year expected results to be ahead of expectations.

FX

GBP - Far from zero to hero, but Sterling is ahead of the pack in terms of broad G10 currency advances vs the Greenback as the DXY ducks back under the 97.000 level. Cable has bounced further from yesterday’s new 2018 low circa 1.2507, through the pre-official cancellation of the Brexit vote base around a big figure higher and just shy of 1.2640, mainly on short covering and consolidation, but also with the aid of strong UK average earnings. Meanwhile, Eur/Gbp has retreated towards 0.9000 having cleared 0.9050 and topped out not too far from 0.9100.

EUR/CHF/SEK/NOK - The next best majors, with the single currency maintaining its recovery momentum off 1.1350 lows vs the Usd, but capped ahead of 1.1400 and perhaps conscious of hefty option interest between 1.1390 and the bog figure (2 bn). The Franc remains relatively firm within a 0.9905-0.9865 range and above 1.1250 vs the Eur, while the Scandi crowns have clawed back recent losses amidst an improvement in risk sentiment, and with the Sek awaiting Swedish inflation data on Wednesday after significantly stronger than forecast Norwegian CPI metrics yesterday. Eur/Nok is around 9.7000 and Eur/Sek back below 10.3000.

JPY - Also trying to pare losses vs the Dollar after extending its downturn from 112.25 to 113.35 and extremely close to a Fib level, but unable to rebound through 113.00 where heavy supply is touted and a 1.5 bn option expiry resides.

AUD/CAD/NZD - Mixed fortunes once again as the Aud reclaims 0.7200+ status vs its US counterpart, albeit just, on more promising vibes regarding US-China trade, which have also nudged the Aud/Nzd cross back up towards 1.0500, as the Kiwi losses sight of 0.6900 vs the Usd. Meanwhile, the Loonie is back on the 1.3400 handle and regaining some composure alongside crude prices.

EM - The Try continues to underperform on bearish technical rather than fresh fundamental impulses, but did glean support from another upbeat snapshot of Turkey’s current account to trade back near 5.3500 vs the Dollar from 5.4000+ at one stage.

FIXED INCOME

Core EU debt has slipped further into the red, with Gilts still lagging peers (down over 50 ticks) as the UK benchmark saw a little more bearish reaction to UK wage data, despite focus remaining on Brexit updates, with no-confidence speculation mounting. Traders are now eyeing a fib at 123.48 on the downside as support vs. Liffe lows of 123.59. Bunds saw little reaction to a decent Schatz auction (b/c and average yield falling in line with prev.) or ZEW with 10-year yields now firmer above 0.25% as the risk-on tone has replaced yesterday’s safe haven flight (for now at least). Back to futures on a technical basis 162.82 is up next as support as the benchmark  hangs around the 162.90 handle vs. 162.83 at worst. BTPs remain cautious ahead of tomorrow’s Italian-EU budget showdown as sources suggest Rome is not stepping back from its 2.2% target. OATs are also deeply in the red, with the French 10-year yield rising above 0.75% at one point and hitting a three week high, as protestors seem unappeased by President Macron’s concessions amid calls for a 5th week of action.

Elsewhere, US Treasury futures are seeing most of the action in the belly ahead of the USD 38bln 3yr auction amidst a concessionary tone as 10-year futures broke the 120-16/17 level to the downside with 120-06 eyed next up and yields above 2.85%.

COMMODITIES 

Brent (+0.9%) and WTI (+1.0%) prices have strengthened, despite drifting lower at the start of the session following comments from Russian Energy Minister Novak that Russia plans to cut oil output by 50k-60k BPD in January; which is significantly below the 228,000 BPD figure targeted as part of the latest OPEC deal. Novak adds that they will gradually reduce oil output. Separately, high level internal reports are to cut output by 139k BPD following the OPEC deal. Looking ahead today sees the API weekly data release, which saw a crude stocks build of 5.6mln last week.

Gold has strengthened on a softer dollar, although the yellow metal is still off of the 5-month high of USD 1250.55/oz reached in the previous session. Separately, exploration by Rio Tinto in Australia has yet to find any economically viable copper ore veins; the site had been touted as being potentially rich in copper.

Iranian oil exports have improved since early November according to the Iranian President. (Newswires)

subject: China reportedly moving to cut auto tariffs on US cars
content:
• The proposal has been submitted for review, however, the decision has not been finalised and still could change
  • Proposal reportedly is to reduce tariffs on US auto imports to 15% form 40%
reaction_details: In an immediate reaction EU auto names spiked higher; Daimler from EUR 46.10 to EUR 46.90; Volkswagen from EUR 144.5 to EUR 146.30
analysis_details: After the G20 meetings had concluded, Trump tweeted that "China has agreed to reduce and remove tariffs on cars coming into China from the U.S. Currently the tariff is 40%" (3/Dec), although this was not reflected in the official statement from China. As such, market participants were unclear whether China was truly committed to achieving a deal with regards to autos, or whether US President Trump had embellished he outcome of his meeting with China. Today's news suggested that such an agreement was discussed, and as such, is positive in terms of taking steps to resolve the trade dispute

content: Gilts have returned to Liffe under heavy selling pressure, and just extended losses to 59 ticks at 123.63 after a fleeting attempt to regain some lost ground from an initial print of 123.74 fizzled out at 123.87. The downturn is partly corrective, as Bunds also made more room for the rebound in EU stocks and risk appetite in general (162.94 low, -46 ticks), but largely Brexit-related following Monday’s antics that culminated in the cancellation of today’s meaningful vote. All eyes now on the next Parliamentary debate, and any headlines featuring PM May’s latest attempts to prize a bit more from the EU on back-stop terms that might appease Whitehall MPs and improve prospects of a positive result when the deferred vote does take place. Back to Liffe, Short Sterling futures have been 4 ticks below parity in the run up to jobs and wage data.

However, the core Eurozone bond may retain an underlying bid as BTPs remain cautious ahead of tomorrow’s Italian-EU budget showdown and as French OATs continue to decline on the deteriorating fiscal outlook following President Macron’s U-turn on budget plans amidst all the protests. Moreover, Bunds may glean some traction via December’s ZEW survey if sentiment is worse than forecast like Sentix on Monday, though there could be a bit more concession at the short end ahead of Eur3 bn Schatz supply.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

11th December 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mixed as sentiment in the region only found mild solace from the tech-led recovery on Wall St. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was firmer at the open in which outperformance in the tech sector helped the index pick itself up from around 2-year lows although this later stalled amid weakness in energy and financials, while Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) swung between gains and losses due to a lack of fresh drivers and an indecisive currency. Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) and Hang Seng (-0.2%) were also choppy on trade uncertainty amid lingering concerns the Huawei situation could spill-over to US-China trade talks, although there were reports that Vice Premier Liu spoke with US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and US Trade Representative Lighthizer in which they exchanged views on pushing forward the timetable and road map for the next stages of trade discussions. Meanwhile, India markets were initially pressured following the shock resignation by RBI Governor Patel which many viewed to be in protest for government meddling, while the state assembly elections added to the woes for the government with the ruling BJP party on track to lose some states to the main opposition ahead of next year’s general election

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 11th December 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets were mixed as sentiment in the region only found mild solace from the tech-led recovery on Wall St.
  • A source said Brexit vote could take place in early January, although a spokesman for UK PM May said doesn't think PM May established a new Brexit deal vote date
  • Reports suggest Italian PM Conte is targeting a 2.1% deficit, whilst Deputy PMs Salvini and Di Maio refuse a deficit of below 2.2% and the EU demand a target of 1.95%
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK Employment Data, German ZEW, US PPI, US 3yr Note Auction, German 2020 Schatz Auction

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mixed as sentiment in the region only found mild solace from the tech-led recovery on Wall St. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was firmer at the open in which outperformance in the tech sector helped the index pick itself up from around 2-year lows although this later stalled amid weakness in energy and financials, while Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) swung between gains and losses due to a lack of fresh drivers and an indecisive currency. Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) and Hang Seng (-0.2%) were also choppy on trade uncertainty amid lingering concerns the Huawei situation could spill-over to US-China trade talks, although there were reports that Vice Premier Liu spoke with US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and US Trade Representative Lighthizer in which they exchanged views on pushing forward the timetable and road map for the next stages of trade discussions. Meanwhile, India markets were initially pressured following the shock resignation by RBI Governor Patel which many viewed to be in protest for government meddling, while the state assembly elections added to the woes for the government with the ruling BJP party on track to lose some states to the main opposition ahead of next year’s general election. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful amid the indecisive risk tone and with participants following mixed results at the 30yr JGB auction.

PBoC skipped repos although are expected to resume operations soon to fill year-end short-term liquidity gaps. (Newswires/CSJ)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8996 (Prev. 6.8693)

China Mofcom said Vice Premier Liu He spoke by phone with US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade Representative Lighthizer in which both sides exchanged views on implementing consensus reached by their leaders, while they also exchanged views on pushing forward timetable and road map for next stage of trade discussions. (Newswires)

China is to announce details of fist purchase of US soybeans, in which most will be added to state reserves. (Newswires)

Huawei CFO bail hearing ended without a decision and will resume today. Reports also noted that Canada Crown commented on the defence’s proposal of CAD 15mln for bail of Huawei CFO in which it stated that bail should be half cash and half home equity, while the judge was said to want a house arrest for Huawei CFO. (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK PM May said she doesn't believe the scenario where the government delays the Brexit vote until March is correct and that the the EU hasn't been engaging with the UK in regard to mitigating a no deal on both sides of the border.  (Newswires)


A source said Brexit vote could take place in early January, although a spokesman for UK PM May said doesn't think PM May established a new Brexit deal vote date which will depend on her getting reassurance on the backstop. (Newswires)

European Council President Tusk says we will not renegotiate the deal, including the backstop, but ready to discuss how can facilitate UK ratification. (FT) Note, UK PM May is to meet with European Commission head Juncker later today.

UK Secretary of State for Work and Pensions Rudd said PM May is committed to maintaining the backstop in the agreement and trying to get reassurance on whether it can be temporary. (Newswires)

UK Tory Brexiteer Rees-Mogg said if PM May returns with the backstop removed, most problems are solved and that agreeing an end date for the backstop would not be enough. (Newswires)

UK Opposition Leader Corbyn said the Labour party will not table a no confidence motion prior to the Brexit vote. (Newswires)

UK Parliament will hold a 3-hour debate today to defer the meaningful vote. (Newswires)
 

French President Macron believes there is a way out of current problems, while he stated that overtime pay will not be taxed and has asked the government to increase minimum wage by EUR 100/month from January. Furthermore, Macron said the increase in social security tax for pensioners earning less than EUR 2,000/month will be scrapped in 2019 and that the wealth tax won't be reinstated. (Newswires) In the wake of this announcement, reports suggest the 2019 deficit/GDP ratio is likely to be around 3.5%. (Les Echos)

EU's Moscovici said Italy has been showing more willingness to cooperate on the budget, but added they are preparing next steps for possible disciplinary procedure while talks continue with Italy. Elsewhere, there were comments from EU Commissioner Dombrovskis who noted rising risks to the European economy and said the time is very limited for Italians to make any substantial changes to the 2019 budget. (Newswires) Later it was reported that Italian PM Conte is targeting a 2.1% deficit, however, separate reports suggest, Deputy PMs Salvini and Di Maio refuse a deficit of below 2.2%, whilst the EU are reportedly demanding a deficit target of 1.95%. (La Repubblica/Messaggero)

FX

In FX markets, the major pairs quietened from yesterday’s price moves which provided GBP/USD with some much-needed respite following its slip to 20-month lows in the fall-out of PM May’s 11th hour cancellation of the Brexit deal vote. EUR/USD also languished after its recent weakness and although it has bounced off support at 1.1350 the recovery is only modest as the DXY remains firm above 97.00. Elsewhere, AUD/USD was choppy around the 0.7200 level and USD/JPY just about held on to the 113.00 handle amid the mixed risk-tone, while focus was also on the INR after RBI Governor Patel’s shock resignation which saw USD/INR gap higher by 1.6% at the open and prompted suspected RBI intervention.  
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly uneventful in which WTI crude futures consolidated around the USD 51.00/bbl after the prior day’s resumed downtrend that saw prices drop over 3% due to an initial risk averse tone and firmer greenback. Elsewhere, gold prices nursed losses overnight and set course back towards resistance around the USD 1250 level, while copper also rebounded amid an improvement in global risk sentiment.

US


Treasuries ended Monday’s session lower as equities rebounded and pared back some of their losses. The complex hit session highs at the European close on confirmation that PM May will delay Tuesday’s Brexit vote in parliament, before edging lower ahead of this week’s supply. Most of the action was concentrated in the front end of the curve were yields were higher by c1bps at settlement. 2s30s and 5s30s were narrower by c.3bps while 2s5s widened by less than 1bps. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 2+ ticks lower at 120-22.

US President Trump is said to be concerned regarding an impeachment and sees it as a real possibility according to sources. (CNN)
